chapter: Dr. Oliver sat in his office, hunched over a small desk littered with papers. A dull light from the corner cast an eerie glow through the small room. It had been several hours since he had talked to Jana. How could he tell her what he needed to say? Did it even matter?  Alice, one of the nurses, knocked lightly on his door.  "Come in." "John, may I sit with you?" she asked.  Dr. Oliver became frustrated at the interruption to the silence and angrily waved her off. "No, it wouldn't do any good," he growled, wanting to be left to himself.   Alice came in anyway, and stood next to him, tenderly rubbing his shoulder. He tensed up slightly. Sometimes, her touch felt just like the woman he lost years ago. But he knew it would never be quite the same. "Its times like these when you need someone," she said. "Just tell Jana the truth. We can't keep her here against her will." Dr. Oliver retracted his arm and bounced up. "We can't? I don't know if you've noticed Alice, but it's not exactly law and order out there," he hissed at her. "I helped bring her back! I will talk to her on my time." "Doctor, you are not God," Alice said gently, trying to calm him down. "There is no God. He would have helped already," he said with a streak of bitterness. "Doctor, please. Talk to her," Alice pleaded.  Dr. Oliver sat back down and shifted restlessly in his chair.  "Please," Alice asked again. "Fine dammit! Just, just give me a second," Dr. Oliver responded, not wanting to fight with her. He was worn out enough as it was, and realized his anger was not worth the energy.  "Good, I knew I could count on you," Alice responded, lightly kissing him on the cheek.  She walked out of the room, leaving Dr. Oliver to his own thoughts. He opened a drawer in his desk and pulled out a small, threadbare stress ball and began to anxiously squeeze it. Each squeeze began to synchronize with his racing heartbeat. Gathering himself after several moments, he walked out of his office, down the hall towards the medical ward. Scanning his identification card, he entered Jana's room.  "Sorry about earlier. May I please talk?"  "Please," Jana said.  Dr. Oliver tried to make small talk. "Comfortable?" Jana stared at him wryly. "I think you know the answer to that." "I'm just going to try to start where I left off," Dr. Oliver started to say, before clearing his throat, as if to stall time. "Jana, this enemy couldn't live in our world. They needed a way to adapt, so they..." he trailed off.  "They what?" she asked. "They needed a way to live out here. So, they took the victims they killed in battle and... And they began to harvest their DNA... creating replica bodies in some sort of lab, we think. They were going to use these bodies as hosts to transfer their consciousness into. The government at the time thought they were manufacturing some sort of microchip technology.  This technology was going to be used to transfer their consciousness into these manufactured host bodies. Then they would be able to live in our world. Only they wanted to enhance them into some sort of metahuman body." "So what does that have to do with me?" Jana asked.  Dr. Oliver sighed, drained. "Well, in order to fight back, the government began creating cyborg bodies with enhanced, almost superhuman strength and agility. But the science was not advanced enough. The government wanted to create these synthetic super soldiers. They would give them armored exteriors, but still wanted sentient consciousness. They wanted to transfer the organic organs of highly-skilled warriors into these bodies. Human on the inside, but machine on the outside.

Dr. Oliver and several other members of the compound walked out into the open. Above them was a giant hexagonal metal ship, illuminated by flashing lights, hundreds of yards long floating about a hundred feet over the ground. A large runway began to come out of the bottom. A black, bearded man appearing in his 40s started down it, flanked by several armed guards on each side. The sides of his head were shaved and sprinkled with gray. He wore a large black trenchcoat, over what appeared to be a bulletproof vest. He looked completely human except for one of his arms, which was outfitted with several cybernetic enhancements, leading to an artificial hand.  "We are becoming quite familiar," he said to Dr. Oliver.  "Aram, please," Dr. Oliver begged, "we can't afford to give you anymore." "That's not my concern," Aram responded flatly. "I need five workers. Now."  Dr. Oliver turned and looked pleadingly at Dr. Kaji. Head down in shame, Dr. Kaji pointed his arm to a group of residents. Jana, hiding inside the building had gone towards the front entrance and peaked out a window to see what was happening.  "Are they able bodied?" Aram asked him. "Yes, all of them," Dr. Kaji responded, dejected.  "Good," Aram said. "Then I'll take them." The guards flanking him gathered up the group of residents and started escorting them up the ramp onto the ship, pushing and prodding them along. Several screams and cries rang out of from the crowd. Several women began weeping. Aram looked towards the remaining crowd.  "Don't worry, I'll be back," Aram said tauntingly. "You all have a nice day." He walked up the ramp on to the ship as it closed behind him. Then, with a loud, thundering boom, the ship began to fly away into the sky. Watching him leave, Dr. Oliver distraughtly turned to Dr. Kaji. "We can't keep doing this anymore." "I know," Dr. Kaji agreed. "We have no choice. We... we have to launch a sixth rebellion."

Jana and Braxton entered Jana's room. By now, instead of a cold metal operating table, the room had been refurbished with a bed, a carpet, and other things to make it more comfortable. Braxton asked Jana if she was okay again, then jogged down the hallway looking to find Dr. Oliver.  Coming back into the room, Braxton said, "I found him. He'll be in here in a few minutes." Jana looked up at him and blushed. "Thanks for helping me." Braxton cleared his throat. He was enamored with how beautiful she looked. "Oh, its no-no problem." "You know, you're the one of the first people I've met on the outside. I've been in this building for weeks and I still don't feel like I know what's going on." "Yeah, I haven't seen you around. I think you're one of the ones the doctors have been building," Braxton said.  "What do you mean?" "Well", Braxton continued, "I know that they've been building robots to help us lead a resistance." "Cyborgs," Jana corrected him. "At least that's what Dr. Oliver said." "Right," Braxton said, mildly embarrassed. "I'm sorry. I know your still part-human right?" "That's what they tell me," Jana joked.  "Yeah," Braxton said laughing awkwardly. "But what I was saying was is that they have been building cyborgs and enhancing people who want to help. I know some of the leaders here have been talking about going out and trying to free some of our people." "Free our people? What people?" Jana inquired. "And why are people talking about this 'resistance'? Can't we just live our lives out here?" Braxton frowned, becoming serious. "No. See the Nexus..." He paused and looked away struggling to finish what he wanted to say. "The Nexus takes people from us. They do it from all the small communities outside of the cities. A couple of times a year, they take some of the stronger people and take them to work for them. You know, like making things for them. Creating their roads and buildings and stuff. It's kind of like forced labor. They're not like locked up or anything, but they have to stay in the city. There's armed guards on the outside." "And you want to get them back?" Jana asked. "Right," Braxton continued. "And we've tried before. We've had like five rebellions I think, and I can only remember one of them pretty well. I was too young but my older brother and father were in it but..."  Braxton started tearing up. "But they never came back. I don't know if they just died or were imprisoned but what does it matter. I'll-I'll never see them again," he said wiping the beginnings of tears from his eyes.  Jana put her hand around his and he gripped it tightly. "The only one I have left is my mom," he went on, "and she doesn't want much to do with me. I think I reminder her too much off how things were before." Jana asked, "Do you have any friends?" Braxton half-smiled. "I have a few acquaintances but this place isn't really somewhere you make friends. I think people are more just focused on surviving, you know?" Jana smiled warmly at him. "Well I'll be your friend. I haven't had any in 20 years...or so they tell me," she laughed.  "20 years? Wow! Is that how long you've been out?" "I guess. Dr. Oliver told me that I was part of some group of soldiers or something. And that I saw something important. Some sort of microchip stuff? I don't know. So he said they recovered some of my brain and my heart. And then preserved it... you know what? This sounds really weird and I'm sorry I'm telling you all this stuff." Braxton started laughing. "Believe me," he said, "this kind of stuff is not that weird these days." Jana laughed back, starting to feel more comfortable with him. She wanted to tell him more. "He said they put my brain and heart in this body." Suddenly, Dr. Oliver walked through the door, interrupting their conversation. "Braxton, thanks for getting me," he said. Turning to Jana he continued, "Did you say you got into a fight?" Looking at him timidly, Jana said, "Yeah there were these three guys. They jumped me." Then, more excitedly she said, "And I beat them up. Really easily. It was weird. How did I do that?" Dr. Oliver shook his head, irritated. "I told you... there are a lot of things you are going to be able to do. But you can't just go out and assault people," he said sternly. "But I didn't! They jumped me," Jana retorted.  "Jana, it doesn't matter," Dr. Oliver rebuked. "You can't put yourself in a situation like that to begin with. Do you know how it looks? This... science that we are doing here. Not everyone thinks Project Amaran is a good idea... creating these soldiers." He continued "Hell, I don't even know if it's a good idea. It feels like we're playing God. Bringing people back from the brink of death... it's not natural. But when you are fighting for your freedom... I guess you will do anything."  Jana ignored him and pointed to Braxton. "He told me that the Nexus takes people. Is that true?" Dr. Oliver snuck a look at Braxton then nodded solemnly. "Yes, and they should be here again any day now too. We can't keep giving them any more people or soon we won't be able to survive out here. And I think that's what they want." Confused, Jana said, "Then why don't you just leave? Hide and start a new life somewhere else?" "There's nowhere to go," Dr. Oliver said. "It's a wasteland out there and even if we tried... what kind of life would that be?" "And what kind of life is this?" Braxton responded.  Dr. Oliver looked at him dejectedly. He did not know what to say.  All of a sudden, there was a large booming sound overhead and the ground began to shake.  "Oh, crap! They're here," Braxton shouted.  "Jana, stay in here! They cannot find you. You are too valuable!" Dr. Oliver screamed.  Terrified, Jana asked "What's going on?" "The Nexus is here to take from us."

Year 2300 It had been a year since the enemy had first touched down. There were no human strongholds left and mankind was losing ground fast. The African Republic as well as the Oceanic Federation had completely collapsed. All that remained were scattered refugee camps, bunkering down, waiting for the war to pass.  In one of the camps, rubble of what once used to be building littered the vast wasteland around it. Ashes rained down from the sky, dusting the ground below. All inhabitants had died, except for a remaining few. A young woman was laying down on the cold earth, screaming in agony. Dark veins covered her body, beginning to engulf her face.  John stared at her, forcing himself to maintain his composure, desperately trying to help. Another man hurried beside him.  "How bad is it?" the man asked, catching his breath.  "It's bad, Lee," John replied. "I did a full body scan. It's spread through her entire body, except for a few parts in her central nervous system. The heart doesn't seem to be effected either, but I'm really not sure." Lee nodded solemnly. "At least the most important parts are still intact. If you want to save her, we're going to need to start the procedure now." John hesitated and Lee squeezed his shoulder reassuringly. "Your mother said to do everything in your power to save her. You promised her." John nodded slowly, containing his emotions. He let out a deep breath. "Okay, then let's get started." Lee picked up the woman and placed her on dental steel table as John covered her face with an oxygen mask. Then he pulled out a bag with several sharp surgical instruments, along with a large glass jar.  "This isn't going to work," he said, stifling back tears, as he cut into her flesh with a scalpel.  "It will work. If you don't try it, it's certain death," Lee countered. "We know what they are working on. In a few years, we can try to save her. But right now we have to preserve what's left. I promise you John, we'll bring her back."

Aram sat on a balcony in one of the towering skyscrapers overlooking the city slums. Colorful lights illuminated the dark sky. In one hand, he clutched a large syringe, containing a lyme green substance. Closing his eyes and exhaling, he injected it into his arm, draining the serum into him. As Aram tried to ignore the searing pain, he tried listening to the noises down below. A knock on the door interrupted him, and he pulled the syringe out of his arm.  "What?" he barked.  The door opened and the woman with the snake tattoo and mohawk walked up to him.  "What is it Largo?" Aram asked, not looking at her.  "Sir," the woman said, "There was this girl Amiris and I saw tonight..." "And... what?" Aram asked indifferently. "Sir, we were in a bar and these guys were picking on her. Big guys. And she just kicked their asses. Like, she threw a guy across the room," Largo said.  Aram stared ahead and nodded knowingly.  "And, sir... there was something about her. She looked human but... not quite. Like almost artificial." "Almost like some kind of machine?" Aram asked.  "I guess so. Something like that," Largo said.  "The Nexus does not use that kind of technology," Aram said flatly, reclining back his chair.  "Sir, I swear I saw..." Largo began.  "Oh I believe you, Largo. And I think I know what you saw," Aram said. "Have you heard anything about super soldiers?" Largo shook her head.  "Well," Aram continued, "We believe that some rebels were trying to construct these... soldiers. To rebel against the Nexus, not realizing it's pointless, of course. I shut down their compound. And had one of these soldiers killed. And I shot the man in charge in the head." "But, sir. They must have sent one to fight the Nexus," Largo said. "Or she just defected," Aram countered.  "Yes, but..." Aram put his hand up to stop her. "Don't worry. I want you to keep an eye on her." Largo nodded.  "And don't do anything rash. You know I'm paying you and Amiris off the book." "Yes sir," Largo agreed.  "But, if she makes a fuss again... kill her," Aram said.  "Yes sir." "What section did this happen in?" Aram asked.  "Section 12, sir." "Okay, then if you should have to kill this girl, I will talk to the head officer, Alon. You will not be held accountable. He answers only to me," Aram said.

Jana and Athena walked into a rundown apartment-like structure.  "So this is factory housing?" Jana asked, soaking in the surroundings.  "I guess so. What a dump," Athena responded.  An overweight man with a clunky, rusty robotic arm walked up to them. "Are you guys new residents?" he asked.  "They told us to go here," Jana said. "They assigned us to cybernetics at the Production Center." "Then you're in the right place," the man said, extending his hand. "I'm Matt. I run this building. Let me get you all set up." Matt led them to the lobby and went behind a desk.  "Okay, so rent is 4000 points a week," he said. "Here are keys to your rooms. Rooms 104 and 115. Same floor." He handed them two worn keys. "May I see your ID cards?" he asked.  Jana and Athena handed him their cards. Matt took out a scanner and scanned the IDs. "Okay, you have 1000 points left on your cards," he said, handing the IDs back to them. "Each room comes with basic furniture and stuff. It's not much but it's enough to get by." Saying goodbye to Matt, the two women went up a flight of stairs to their rooms. The wallpaper was peeling and smelled of mold. Jana had a small, cracked window looking out onto a city street. She could hear shouting and honking outside as people flitted by down below.  After Athena went away to her apartment, Jana decided to get something to eat. She had not had any food since her snack in the afternoon and was starving. Walking down the stairs, Matt greeted her.  "How is it?" Matt asked.  "It's fine," Jana said, lying. "Are there any places for food here?" Matt nodded. "Yeah, there's a small bar a couple minutes down the road. It's called 'Jack's'." "Thanks," Jana said.  "No problem" Matt answered. "It's nice. A little old fashioned. The way things were before the wars." Jana walked down the street outside of her apartment. The air was damp and smelled like rotten eggs. Everything was rushing by her in fast motion. It was so much different that the compound, she thought. A few men zoomed by in old motorbikes, their engines sputtering. Jana noticed there were no lanes for traffic. Everyone just walked wherever they wanted.  An older balding man was standing with a vending cart a few steps ahead of her.  "Dream serums! Buy some dream serums" he shouted. "They're cheap! Only 100 points!" Jana apprehensively approached the man.  "Hi," she said nervously.  "Hey, how many would you like?" he asked her.  "Well, actually I was wondering how you got them?" Jana asked.  The man stared at her with a confused look on his face. "The Nexus rations them out to sell and then they get part of the profit," he answered. "Most people know that. Are you new here or something?" Jana nodded. "Yes, I just got here today actually." "Well, that explains it," the man said, returning to yelling for customers.  "Wait," Jana said.  "Look lady, do you want to buy some or not?" he barked.  "How does the Nexus get them?" Jana asked.

Later that evening, as the sun was beginning to set, Jana began to walk to the entrance of the compound. She was nervous and unsure of herself. What was it like on the outside? Was it safe to go the Nexus? Jana tried to shake the doubtful thoughts out of her head. She reasoned there was no other choice. Either she could go to the Nexus, or live out the rest of her life in a pointless exile. She had avoided Doc for the rest of the day, and told him nothing of her plans. She knew that he would disapprove of her going to the Nexus, but she had no allegiance to him anymore.  As Jana approached the entrance, she saw Athena standing there waiting for her. Athena grinned when she saw Jana coming.  "Good, you made it," Athena said.  The entrance to the compound was a large steel door, stretching around twenty feet high flanked by a large metal wall. The door was cracked open, and people had been abandoning the compound most of the day.  "Are you ready?" Athena asked.  "Yes." "Once we go through this door, there is no going back," Athena cautioned.  "I know." Athena, nodded and walked through the door opening. Jana followed close behind. Looking at the outside world for the first time, Jana saw a barren desert of red sand. On the horizon, seven enormous towers protruded from the ground, stretching thousands of feet high, illuminated by lights in the waning sunlight.  "That," Athena said, pointing to the buildings, "Is the Nexus." Jana gasped. The city seemed so massive, that it almost stretched into the clouds.  "Okay, let's go," Athena urged.  They began to walk through the massive desert. Shortly after leaving the compound, the sun had completely set, and the moon shed a small light on their path.  Jana and Athena walked for many hours before Athena dropped her bag.  "We should stop for the night and start a fire," Athena said.  Jana agreed and they gathered what little debris they could find around them, and set it ablaze with their lighter. Athena opened her backpack and handed Jana some snacks she had brought along.  As they stared in silence at the fire, Athena began to speak. "Thank you for coming with me," she said.  "Yeah, of course," Jana said. "I don't know if I would have had the courage to follow through with it if you didn't come," Athena said. "I really don't think I could have gone with anyone else. I... I feel like you are the only one who could really understand me." "What do you mean?" Jana asked, peering into her dark, almond-shaped eyes.  "What's it like to be... me," Athena said, becoming slightly emotional. "You know- like this." She held up her hands. "Not really human." Jana looked at Athena, listening to the soft crackle of the fire. "How did you end up like this?" she finally said. Athena looked down. "I was in the fifth rebellion against the Nexus. My parents were killed and... I wanted to fight back. Even if I knew I would die. So, other survivors and I banded together to fight. But I got injured. Badly and I..." She trailed off.  The two of them sat in silence for several minutes. Jana noticed tears in Athena's eyes. Athena cleared her throat and tried to talk but stopped herself several times.  Finally, she said, "I got hurt badly and I was dying. There was a guy named Khalil in my group and he saved me. He took me with him and we found a compound. The compound you and I were just in. And, he found out about the work Dr. Oliver was doing, he asked him to help me. Dr. Oliver put what was left of me in this body. He said I was his first one."  She smiled at Jana. "I was so alone. I felt like some kind of freak. I thought that they should have just let me die on my own. And then- Dr. Oliver made Ryker and I had someone else like me. I felt like there was someone who could understand me.  Then they made you and I thought that maybe life wouldn't be so bad... you know? I was still sad, but I thought that maybe there would be more like us. But I didn't want to fight anymore. I just wanted to live my life. But... Dr. Oliver said that people needed me. That we needed to fighto restore freedom. And then... that guy from the Nexus came to the compound and killed Ryker. I... I didn't know what to do. Then they called of the rebellion and..." she trailed off.  Jana put her hand on Athena's shoulder. "It's okay," she said soothingly.  Athena mustered up a half-smile. "They called off the rebellion, and I didn't know where to go or what to do," she said.  "I have felt alone too," Jana admitted.  "But, I'm not strong like you," Athena went on. "You have a real purpose. Dr. Oliver said you saw the enemy's technology. If you can remember where it is, you can stop the Nexus from getting it and help people and..." Jana started shaking her head and cut her off. "No. That was all a lie." "What?" "Doc told me. I never saw any microchip technology. I'm no more important than anyone else," Jana said sadly.  Athena looked confused. "Then why would he bring you back?" "He said that... he said that I was his little sister," Jana explained. "And he couldn't bear to lose me. So he brought me back." Mouth agape, Athena asked, "Well why wouldn't he just tell us the truth?"  "Doc said they wouldn't have let him bring back just anyone. He had to get approval. And they would never have let him use me." Athena sighed in disbelief. "Well, at least you have someone. I don't have anyone to go to." Jana shrugged her shoulders. "I don't have anyone to go to either. I don't even know if he is telling the truth." They both sat in silence as the fire let out another slight crackle. Suddenly, Athena inched towards Jana. She lifted up her hand and gently touched Jana's face. Her skin almost felt real. Athena looked in Jana's eyes.  "You are like me. We have each other," she said.

Jana sat across from Sean in a crowded gym acting as some kind of fallout shelter. Sean looked at her and smiled as people moved hurriedly around them. They each had one small cot, and some basic food that Jana ate hungrily. Various military personnel were stationed throughout the building.  "It's going to be okay," Sean assured her. "We're going to get through this and everything is going to go back to normal and we'll be okay." Jana gradually became lucid and realized she was in a dream. She remembered what Dr. Oliver had told her. Sean was not real; this was all someone else's memory.  "Sean," she asked trying to get answers, "What's my name?" Sean, seemingly confused responded, "Danielle, of course." "No, Sean," Jana said. "That is not my name. Are you my boyfriend?" Sean, again looking confused said, "As far as I know." Jana shook her head. "No." Sean looked hurt. "What do you mean?" "I'm not Danielle. And I'm not your girlfriend." Sean let out a small, nervous chuckle. "Dani, stop joking around." As Jana was asking Sean questions, a man in a military uniform at the other end of the room grabbed a microphone.  "Folks, listen up!" he yelled. The room quieted down. "It is my deep regret to inform you that... Los Angeles has fallen to the enemy."  Scattered gasps sounded from the crowd.  "And," he continued, "Not only that, but... there appears to be some kind of... disease spreading. People are getting some sort of virus and dying. It has already wiped out several cities." Sean exchanged a worried glance with Jana.  "And three-quarters of the American Alliance's armed forces have been... eradicated," the man continued. "I have officially been given permission by my superiors to ask for volunteers. If anyone in this room wants to try to take our world back... the time is now. I beg you to help us."  He put down the microphone and people began clamoring. Another man walked up from behind him and picked the microphone up. "If anyone here would like to help us, please raise your hand and come to the front of the room." "You're the military! Do your jobs," a man yelled angrily from the crowd.  "There's no stopping it," another man screamed. "It's the apocalypse. The world is ending!" The soldier grabbed the microphone again. "Please, keep order! If we don't work together we will die." Several children began crying. Their parents tried to calm them, but the children would not stop.  "Please! Raise your hand if you can help us," the soldier begged again.  Jana found herself raising her hand. "Dani, what are you doing?" Sean whispered intensely.  Jana looked at himwith intensity. "I'm going to fight."

Jana sat on her bed, hot tears streaming down her face and falling down her sheets. She felt like an outsider, even in her own body because it was not hers. Doc said he was her brother, but even if we was, how could any brother do something so selfish? And he told her that her mother was dead. She had no one. She knew she could not stay at the compound, but where could she go? Was the Nexus really as bad as Doc said it was?  She lifted up the bottom of her shirt, revealing the metal parts of her body, not covered in synthetic skin. It made her uncomfortable to see them. It seemed too foreign to her, but it reminded her of what she was.  Jana heard a faint knock at her door. "Come in," she said, wiping away tears.  The door opened and Jana saw Athena at the entrance. She was surprised, as Athena had never said much to her. She always seemed to prefer keeping to herself.  "Hey," Athena said.  "Hey," Jana responded.  Athena sat next to Jana on her bed. "I'm going to the Nexus tonight," Athena said in a hushed tone, "And I want to know if you will come with me." "The Nexus? Why?" Jana asked stunned.  "Well, I've been thinking... there's not going to be a rebellion here. And everyone's leaving the compound. So do we just stay out in the desert to die?" Jana started to object, but could not think of what to say.  "And what if the Nexus isn't that bad," Athena continued, "Maybe that guy was right with what he was saying. I didn't sign up for this stuff here." Jana sighed. Athena made a good point. "So will you go with me? I don't want to go alone. And you're the only one left here that's...like me." Jana thought about what Athena was saying. She knew she could not stay in the compound. And she did not want to go out into the desert. And she felt like she could not trust Doc. Even if he was telling the truth, what kind of family did that make him? "Okay," Jana said hesitantly. "I'll go." "Great. I have a lighter and some food in a backpack," Athena said.  "What do we need a lighter for?" "It's gonna take about 24 hours to get there, so we need to stop to rest and make a fire," Athena explained.  "Why are we walking?" Jana asked, confused.  Athena nodded. "There's very little vehicles here because people almost never leave the compound. Most people who left already took the motorbikes we had." "Is it safe? To go on foot?" Jana asked.  Athena began chuckling. "With how strong we are, I don't think anyone is going to mess with us." Jana forced a smile, but Athena's face took a more serious tone. "Meet me at the entrance to the compound in three hours."

The woman was running through dense enemy fire. Lasers rushed past her face, as she stumbled through wreckage. She knew she had just seen something very important but she did not know what. After a few moments, she noticed a young man running with her.  "Look out!" she shouted at him.  A plasma blast shot him in the chest, completely disintegrating him. Terrified, she turned look behind her, to face a tall humanoid figure, wearing metallic black armor and a helmet-like device obscuring his face. He fired at her, with the blast narrowly missing. Fear coursing through her body, she ran as fast as she could.   The woman awoke, suddenly. She must have somehow fallen asleep, exhausted by all of her panic. Looking down at her body, it became clear that it was not quite human, but some kind of artificial body designed to mimic a natural one. Under her gown, she could see that she looked purely cybernetic, made of some kind of high grade steel.   On her shoulder, she saw numbers engraved Z3. She looked down, slowly turning her legs. There was a small mechanical sound. She glanced down at her toes and slowly moved them. She was scared to see what her face looked like.  After she had, been awake for a few moments, the door opened and Doctor Oliver entered, this time without Dr. Kaji.  "Good morning. Here, have this." Dr. Oliver handed her a protein bar. Dr. Oliver smiled, pulling out a chair from the corner of the room and sitting next to the table. "Do you know what your name is?" he asked.  Without thinking she responded, "Jana." The word just popped into her head, but it felt right to say, almost instinctual.  "Right!" Dr. Oliver said, his face lighting up. "Good." He paused briefly. "Jana, I know you have a lot of questions. When you are ready, I would like to tell you why you are here." He looked at her and laughed kindheartedly. "It would probably be easier for you to eat this if I undid those metal cuffs. Can I trust you to be calm?"  Jana looked him over. Still feeling very uneasy, she decided it was best to trust him, or at least pretend to. "Yes," she said.  "Good," Dr. Oliver said. He walked over to a small computer screen at the back of the room and typed in a small code. The shackles snapped open.  "You didn't poison these did you?" Jana looked at her food, half joking.  "Haha, no. That would mean I wasted a lot of time bringing you back," Dr. Oliver said.  Jana bit into her food apprehensively.  She looked intently at him. "What is this? What did you to me? This is not...me." Dr. Oliver looked at her understandingly. "You have been away for a very long time. Do you remember how you died?" "Died?" A wave of alarm pulsed through Jana.  Dr. Oliver nodded, and struggled to explain everything to her. "Jana, mankind was attacked over 20 years ago, but by an enemy not of this world. History has recorded the battles as the 'Astro Wars.' Some of the younger people in this compound were not even alive to see it. But we have lived here for a generation and have kept records stored on our computer systems." He trailed off and mumbled, "It seems like forever that we have been in this town. Well, I'm not sure we can even call it a town anymore. It's more of a paramilitary compound." He forced a smile, trying to make Jana feel at ease, and then continued.  "This enemy... they released biological weapons on our world. Disease killed probably one-half of the population. We think they wanted to colonize earth. From what we could tell, their species was dying. Their weapons were far more advanced than ours. They could have easily destroyed us but for one thing." He paused again, as if thinking of the right words to say. He began to scratch the grizzle beginning to grow on his face.  "This enemy, these creatures...they couldn't widely colonize us because...well, we think because this atmosphere was toxic to them. Too high a level of oxygen maybe, I don't know. And they started dying when they left their ships. We don't really know why, but we think they were not immune to our diseases. And our food on earth was toxic to them." Jana looked at him suspiciously as he started to continue. She couldn't believe what he was saying. It was all so absurd, she thought. It felt like she was in some kind of dream or trancelike state. This could not be real; it was just preposterous.  "Stop lying to me," she said. "I want to know the truth. Did you and Dr. Kaji kidnap me and bring me here? Is this some kind of sick experiment you're doing?" He seemed to be surprised by what she said and then gathered himself and looked at her stone-faced.  "I wish I was lying. Heaven knows I wish I was." His voice cracked, as if he was starting to fight off tears. Then with a half-hearted laugh he said, "You know you'd think I'd be better at talking about this by now, wouldn't you? It's not like I haven't had the time to cope with it. This is just the way life is here now. But, but that doesn't make it any less hard you know?" She looked at him intently, still not sure whether to trust him or not. But seeing him express vulnerability made her feel a strange sensation. It was almost like compassion, but she could not explain it.  "Go on," she said, curious about what more he had to say.  "Anyway, the food on earth was toxic to them. They could not live here, but they had nowhere else to go. In fact I don't know why they came here, but I think somehow our water supply was valuable to us. As I said, we believe they did not have a world to go back to. And I guess they were no other inhabitable planets. We still have not encountered any other kind of intelligent life. So they had to find a way to survive. And, and..." He seemed to be holding back his emotions. He stopped abruptly, looked at her sadly and said, "I'm sorry that's enough for today. Do you want water?"  He turned to a nurse waiting at the doorway. "Please, bring her some water." Then he smiled at Jana and started to leave. Jana blurted, "Where are you going? You're just going to leave me like this. What did you do to me!?"  "Jana, I will tell you, but I just need time." Dr. Oliver pleaded, as he walked out of the room.  A nurse rushed in with a glass of water. "Here sweetheart, drink this," she said.  Jana ignored her outstretched hand and glared at her. "What am I?" The nurse smiled. "Honey, Dr. Oliver is very stressed and you need to give him time." Feeling a sudden swell of anger, Jana yelled. "I said what am I!" The nurse walked to the door and rested her arm on the frame. Without looking at Jana, she uttered solemnly, "We've already told you. You are our last chance." Then she swiftly exited the room and the door closed behind her.

Jana and Athena walked down a small, crowded street. They were surrounded by rundown metal buildings stretching several dozen stories high. They could see nearby smoke stacks coming from an industrial factory. People walked and rode past them in motorbikes. A vendor stood on street corner yelling about food he was selling.  Another guard sauntered up towards Athena and Jana. He pulled out a scanner and checked their profiles.  "You must be new citizens," he said aloud.  "Yes, we just entered," Jana said.  "I am Aden," he said. "I am in charge of new arrivals in Section 12. I make sure all new citizens are integrated. Come with me." Aden led them to the entrance of a nearby building. He opened the door. "Come inside." Inside was a large table with several people behind it handing out what looked like computerized ID cards.  Aden led Jana and Athena to a line formed in front of the table. Then, he said, "Welcome to the Nexus," before leaving them on their own.  "I guess we stand in this line," Jana said.  After a few minutes, they approached the front of the queue. An older, overweight woman looked up at them from behind the table. "Names?" she asked.  "Athena and Jana." "Last names?" the woman asked.  Athena and Jana stared at each other. "We don't have last names," Jana said.  The woman looked at them with a tired face. "No last names?" she asked.  Athena and Jana shook their heads.  "Fine. What do I care? Your DNA is on profile anyway," the woman muttered. She reached into a drawer under the table, then pulled out a scanner, taking their profiles. Then, using the scanner, she took two small computerized ID cards and scanned them. Jana's and Athena's images appeared on the cards.   "These are your IDs," the woman explained unenthusiastically. "They are good for Section 12 of the city. You start with 5000 points. You can use these to buy things, get places, it doesn't matter." Handing the cards to Jana and Athena, the woman said, "You will be stationed at Production Center 10. That is where you will work if you want more points. You are in the cybernetic enhancements department." Seeing confused looks on their faces, the woman groaned. "Every day you work, you will receive 1000 points, good for spending anywhere in this section." "When do we report to work?" Athena asked.  The woman looked at her with an annoyed expression. "Work day starts at 8 and ends at 6. You have no set days you need to be there, but if you don't work you run out of points. If you have no points for two consecutive days, then you have your citizenship revoked. And if you have your citizenship revoked then you are considered a defector. And if you are a defector, then you are an enemy of the Nexus." "What happens if we're an enemy of the Nexus?" Jana asked.  "I don't know, kid," the woman said, "But we don't see those people again."

Jana sat in an open grassy field under a bright blue sky enjoying a nice warm breeze. Her boyfriend Sean sat with her on a small blanket in the soft grass.  "Did I ever tell you you're beautiful," Sean asked tenderly.  "Haha, yeah maybe a few times," Jana joked.  Sean laughed. "Yeah, I guess I have but it's the truth." Sean brushed her long brown hair out of her face. Then leaning forward he rested his hand on her face and gently kissed her.  "In fact I think I might even...love you," Sean said. Jana felt an involuntary jolt of warmness pulse through her body. She realized that she had strong feelings for him. And maybe it really was love.  As she leaned in to kiss him again, dull boom echoed across the landscape, and the ground vibrated softly.  Sean finished the kiss and stared intently at her, a deep longing showing in his eyes. "I don't know how much time we have left, but I know I want to spend it with you." "Sean don't say that" Jana pleaded desperately. "It's going to be fine. We're going to win and its all going to be over. We're not going to die at eighteen. We have our whole lives ahead of us." Sean chuckled, and lightly stroked her arm. "Maybe, but even if we had all the time in the world left, I know I would still want to spend it with you."  She laughed softly and he laughed too. "Wow, that was kinda corny." Jana woke up abruptly in her bed from the strange dream. It had been nearly two weeks since she had first been revived and she was now walking around the compound for the first time. There were several thousand people, mostly living in rundown shacks. The whole town was surrounded by a tall metal wall.  Dr. Oliver explained that it was for protection against invaders.  "It's the Wild West now. There is very little order out here," he had told her. "Away from the large cities, it is every man for himself. We have survived out here this long because we have taken no chances."  Many of the people in the town seemed to have replaced parts of their body with cybernetic machinery. Some people had mechanical arms or legs, while others had large portions of their body replaced with machinery. Jana asked Dr. Oliver why they were like that.  "It's a hard life out here," he said solemnly. "Some people lose limbs to injury or disease. During the wars, people started getting really sick. It was a horrendous plague. Toxic in their blood and their veins were black. It was terrible."  "You said there were others like me," Jana said, changing the topic. "Yes," Dr. Oliver responded. "Only two, and they are not quite as advanced. We tried this technology on other soldiers before bringing you back, but... usually it was... unsuccessful."  "I want to meet them," Jana said. Dr. Oliver looked at her. "You will." Jana turned to see a young man, probably about the age of 25, running frantically down the road. He was clutching scraps of food in his hands. Behind him was another man chasing him on a motorbike.  The motorbike caught up the man running, and the rider pushed him into the dirt. The bike skidded to a stop and the driver got off, and grabbed the food from the other man. He laughed and spat on him, before mounting his bike and cruising off.  Jana, concerned, ran over to the man to see if he was okay. Dirt and dust covered his dark hair, that he pushed away from his dark brown eyes.  "Are you okay?" Jana asked.

Jana woke up abruptly and stared at the simmering remains of their fire. A dim light shone in the sky, signaling the coming sunrise. A cool breeze blew sand into the air. Athena was already packing her backpack.  "Let's go, Jana," she said. "If we get going now, we can make it to the city by nightfall." Jana nodded distractedly. She was trying to understand what she had just dreamed. Sean had called her Dani. Was that the name of the person whose memories she was having?   "Jana, are you hearing me? Let's go," Athena urged.  Jana got up and the two of them began trudging towards the city. As the sun began to show itself on the horizon, Jana got a clearer view of the city. It completely dominated the horizon in the direction they were going. She saw small circular shapes darting between the buildings and enormous moving images of people.  "What are those things moving?" Jana asked.  "Holograms," Athena explained. "The city has all these holograms advertising different things and stuff. And those little shapes you see flying around? Those are like hover cars." "What? How-how do they have all that stuff?"  Athena smirked. "Jana, not everyone lives in squalor like we did at the compound." Jana shook her head in disbelief. "If it's so much better here, then why were we staying there?" "Don't know. Everyone at the compound said the Nexus is evil. But, at this point... I just want to see for myself," Athena said.  Jana and Athena walked through the day. The sun shone brightly in the sky and the air became hot. The ground was red and dry, with cracks forming in the soil. No tree or cactus was in sight.  "It's so barren," Jana observed.  Athena nodded. "That's what a nuclear holocaust does I guess." She pulled some water and a bag of chips out of her backpack.  "Here have some of this," Athena said, handing them to Jana. "We need to eat something or we're going to pass out." "Why do we even need to eat, anyway?" Jana asked. "Doc said our bodies were all almost completely artificial." "I guess for whatever human parts we do have left," Athena responded. "You still have a human heart and brain, right? You have to keep them working." "I guess so," Jana said, biting into a chip.  Athena pulled out a water for herself and began to guzzle it down. Her long blue hair was matted on her face.  As the afternoon transitioned into early evening, the air began to cool and the two of them began to approach the outskirts of the city. A pit began to form in Jana's stomach. She was uneasy about being so close to the place she had been warned so much about.  As they approached even closer, they saw smaller, rundown buildings. The air stunk of chemicals and waste.  "Those must be the slums," Athena said, pointing forward.  "Is that a road?" Jana asked.  Looking over, Athena saw vehicles moving in this distance.  "Yeah, it must be the road into the city," she said.  "Let's follow it," Jana suggested. They approached the road and walked to the city entrance. Two large guards started towards them. They wore all black, with dark black helmets covering their faces. Jana noticed that they each had large glowing swords attached to belts and were holding huge guns.  "State your business," one of them said.  "We want to go inside," Athena said.  Raising their weapons, the guards asked, "Why? Are you a defector?" "No! No!" Jana insisted. "We've never been before." "Run their profile," one of the guards said to the other. He took out a small tablet and pointed it at Jana. A red ray of light scanned her body. Then the guard turned towards Athena and did the same to her.  "They are not in the system," he said.  "Why are you here?" the other demanded.  "We want to enter," Athena repeated.  "Only citizens may enter." the guard asked, his gun pointed at her.  "Then I want to be a citizen," Athena said.  "And you?" the guard asked Jana.  Jana hesitated. "Jana, say yes!" Athena urged.  "Yes. I do." The guards exchanged a glance. "Then, you must give us your profile," one guard said.  "How do we do that?" Jana asked.  "We must scan you again," the guard said.  "Okay, then fine," Athena agreed.  "What are your names?" the guard asked.  "Jana and Athena," Athena answered.  "No last names?" the guard asked inquisitively.  "We don't have last names," Athena said. The guard looked at his partner skeptically.  He pulled out a small tablet and scanned them again. "Your DNA and profile has been scanned and entered into the Nexus's database of citizens. You are now eligible to enter." The second guard added, "Now that you are a citizen, any departure from the city must be authorized by the Nexus. If you leave on your own, you will be considered a defector." Then, the guards stepped apart allowing Jana and Athena to walk into the city. "Welcome," they said.

Braxton waited anxiously by Jana's room. He had not seen her all day and was beginning to get depressed. Maybe she was too nice to reject him to his face. Sighing in defeat, Braxton decided to leave. As he walked down the hall away from Jana's room, he saw Doc.  "Hey, Dr. O., have you seen Jana?" Braxton asked.  "No, but I don't think she really wants to see me," Doc answered.  "I haven't seen her all day," Braxton said, worried. "I talked to her yesterday and I- I kind of asked her out I guess. She was supposed to meet me by her room today, but I haven't seen her and I think she may just not be into me."  "Sorry," Doc said bluntly. "Can't help you with that. Have you seen Athena though? I haven't seen her either. I knocked on her door earlier today but there was no answer." Braxton shook his head. "Sorry, I haven't seen either of them since yesterday." Upon hearing that, Doc suddenly felt a pang of uneasiness. "Braxton, did you hear any talk about them leaving the compound?" he asked in a hushed tone. Surprised, Braxton said, "No. You don't think they would leave would you?" Doc shook his head. "I don't know. I told her she could leave the compound. I hope she didn't decide to walk off into the desert somewhere."  "Or go to the Nexus," Braxton said offhandedly.  Doc froze. Would Jana have defected to the Nexus? Was she so angry with him that she would do that?  "Braxton," Doc asked urgently, "You didn't hear any talk about her going to there did you?" "No," Braxton said.  "Good," Doc said. He turned and walked briskly down the hall towards Alice's office. When he got to the door, Alice looked up and greeted him.  "Alice," Doc said worriedly, "Have you seen Jana or Athena at all?" Alice shook her head. "No. Why?" "I just have an uneasy feeling that they left and..." "And what?" Alice asked.  "And... went to the Nexus," Doc finished.  Alice looked intently at Doc. "I know Athena was not happy here," she confessed. "It's possible she could have decided to leave after the rebellion failed..." "But you don't think Jana would do you?" Doc asked.  "Why would she have any reason to go there?" Alice asked.  Doc sighed. "Because I... told her the truth," he admitted.  "The whole truth?" Alice asked.  "The whole truth. And she was very upset. I'm afraid that she lost all her trust in me. And maybe she doesn't believe anything I told her. Maybe she even thinks the Nexus is on her side. I-I am really worried she went to the city." Alice stared at Doc. "This is why I said you should have told her the truth from the beginning." Doc sighed. "I didn't know how. I was too much of a coward." Alice smiled gently at him. "There's nothing you can do about it now," she said soothingly.  "I just need to know where she went," Doc said.  "Ask around for her. If no one has seen her by tomorrow, then she probably left the compound," Alice advised.  "Yes, but if she left, where did she go?" Doc asked.  Alice shrugged. "You may never know," she admitted.  "If she went off into the wilderness, or went to survive with a few other stragglers... that is her choice," Doc said. "But if she went to the Nexus I have to go get her. I can't let her stay there. I've already made one big mistake and I'm not going to make another." Alice nodded in agreement. "If you go, I will go with you," she said.  Doc nodded and exited her office. Going door to door in the compound he asked people if they had seen Jana in the last day. None of them had. Doc went to Athena's room again and knocked on the door. Again there was no answer. Growing frustrated, Doc began kicking the door as hard as he could until it broke open. There was no one inside.  Doc let out a wail and collapsed. He did not know what to do. If he went to the Nexus and Jana was not there, then there would be no going back. But if she was there, he had to get her out. After gaining as much of his composure back as he could, Doc dragged himself to his office. Khalil was waiting at the entrance.  "Doc," Khalil said. "I heard you were looking for Jana." "She's gone Khalil. I couldn't find her." "I haven't seen her," Khalil admitted. "But I have heard that Athena was going to the Nexus. And- I don't think she would have the courage to do it alone." Doc shrugged. "She could have brought anyone," he said.  Khalil shook his head. "No. Athena didn't talk to anybody." "Well then she went on her own," Doc said.  Khalil shook his head again. "Someone told me they saw Athena go to Jana's room." "What?" Khalil nodded. "John," he said, "I think they went to the Nexus."

Year 2320 The woman awoke on a cold metal operating table. Dull fluorescent lights lit the room, giving off an eerie glow. A dull metallic hum permeated in the corner from what looked like a holographic computer screen. Across the room, a large metal door sealed off the outside world. Two small windows revealed what looked like the hall of a makeshift hospital on the outside. She tried to sit up, but was unable to, noticing two thick metal restraints on her arms, holding her down.  Immediately, it struck her that something was very wrong. Where was she? How did she get here? What was her name? Her memory seemed to be clouded in a deep, almost impenetrable fog. Looking down she saw she was in some sort of hospital gown, and that her arms looked metallic, like they were covered in a light gloss. Her legs also shinned like they were made of some kind of metal material.  She gasped as she realized something was wrong; this was not her body. She stared at her fingers under the restraints and moved them. As she stretched her hand out, her metal fingers clanked against her palm. After what seemed like several minutes, the metal door lifted and in stepped two women wearing scrubs and breathing apparatuses. They seemed to be dressed as nurses with labcoats over their  medical gear. "The radiation levels are low enough," one of them said, removing her mask. "She's awake!" the other exclaimed. "Get the doctors! They will be happy to see." One of them hurriedly scampered out of the room. The other went up to the woman. "Can you hear me?" she asked. The young woman was disoriented and panicked. Once again, she tried to break through the restraints but was unable. She hesitated to answer. "Who are you?" she finally blurted out.  The nurse laughed. "The doctors will explain all that. But we're the ones who saved you." Then taking a more serious tone, she said, "You don't know how important you are."  As she was talking, footsteps echoed from down the hallway and two men entered the room. One was elderly and small-statured, the other tall and middle-aged, with jet black hair just beginning to sprout grey. Jana noticed a long scar running down his left cheek. The older man mustered up a grin and they sat down next to the table. The younger one picked up a clipboard and began scribbling on a pad.  "Can you hear me?" "Yes she can!" the nurse responded.  "Excellent!" He stared at the woman for a few seconds and then shook his head saying, "Sorry! Where are my manners!? I am Doctor Kaji, and the man with me is Dr. Oliver. Don't worry, you are with friends here. We saved you." He looked at her with eagerness in his eyes. "Can you remember anything?" She looked at him, studying his wrinkled features before quietly responding, "No."  He looked a little disappointed, but seemed to stay optimistic. "That's okay. We will get to that later then. How are you feeling? Can you move?" The woman did not directly answer him. "Why am I restrained?" "Oh sorry! Safety measures. We didn't know how you would react. Or what you would do. This is a very new science. There are only several others like you. And half of the procedures have proved fatal... unfortunately." He smiled more tenderly at her. "You don't know how important you are. Dr. Oliver and I have spent most of our lives researching this technology. And, we are running out of options to save this world and our freedom." Dr. Kaji sensed he was saying too much too fast. He silenced himself.  "But I don't want to overwhelm you right off the bat. Please, rest." Dr. Oliver spoke up, turning to the nurse. "Remove the restraints," he said. "She will be fine, but she must be kept in this room for observation."  "My body. This isn't right. Somethings wrong," the girl exclaimed, becoming concerned, "I don't look right. What procedure!? What did you do!?" She suddenly began to convulse violently, attempting to force herself free.  Dr. Oliver calmly turned back to the nurse. "Actually, perhaps the restraints should be left on for now." Getting up he turned to the woman. "Please relax. I will be back soon. You must be relaxed before I tell you." He paused, looking down. "We are your friends." He and Dr. Kaji whispered something to the nurse and then they excited the room.  Becoming increasingly panicked as she came too, the woman felt a pit in her stomach and a flood of emotion, before hot tears began to stream down her face. Not knowing where she was and how she got here. She could not even remember much about who she was.  Outside of her room, the younger doctor turned to his nurses, shaking his head. "Give it time and make her comfortable." "Damn it John," a nurse said to him, "at least give her food."  Dr. Oliver smirked, "She doesn't need much food right now. There's not much organic matter left to feed. But tomorrow, we will give her some fruit. But for now, we'll keep rationing what we have." He turned, looking back into her room, a scowl beginning to drift across his face. "I pray this works. Without it, we have no chance."

Jana tapped on Doc's door. Seeing her, he smiled. "Come on in." Jana sat down in his chair. "Doc," she said, "Are you okay? You look really... down." Doc let out a slight chuckle. "I gave it away that easily, huh?" he said sarcastically.  Sitting back in his chair he said, "I just thought... if we went down we would... go down fighting, you know? I thought that maybe we could make a difference. That I could make a difference. Do something right for once." "You've done a lot of things right! You've given me life!" Doc looked at Jana with incredible sadness.  Slightly unsettled, Jana changed the subject. "Well what about the microchip technology? We can't just let the Nexus have it right? I mean, that would be terrible. We can't just give up that easily." Doc started to say something, but stopped himself. Jana noticed that his eyes were starting to water. He took his glasses off and rubbed them. Putting them back on, he let out a deep sigh. He looked at Jana with great intensity, which started to unnerve her.  "Jana," he said, "I have to tell you something. And... it's going to be very tough for me to say."  A tear ran down his cheek.  "What is it?" Jana asked, concerned.  Doc sighed. "It was a lie. All of it." "What do you mean?" "There might be microchip technology. There probably is, in fact. And if there is then I'm sure the Nexus is trying to use it. But..." He began to cry hysterically.  "But... that's not why I revived you... not why I created you. You- didn't see any microchip technology. I don't know if anyone alive has. And you were not on some high-tech mission trying to bring down the enemy."  Jana looked at him, confused.  "And why do we even call it the enemy?" he asked, partly talking to himself. "Is it to sound cryptic? Let's just call them what they are. Aliens. They were aliens." Jana started to say something, but Doc quieted her.  "I'm not done yet. I have a lot more I need to say. These aliens... they did attack us. That part is true. And they did kill off many of us. That part is also true. In fact, everything I told you earlier about the war is true. But you were not some soldier. And you didn't die in battle. You were..." "What? I was what?" Jana asked.  Doc looked at her and whispered, "You were my sister."  Jana looked at him, bewildered, "What do you mean?" "Jana, you were my little sister. When the enemy..." he said, he voice breaking. "When the enemy came here... they released a biological weapon. It made a lot of people sick. It made you sick. It made our mother sick. She told me to... made me promise to save you.  Our mother... she died. And I... didn't know what to do but at least I had you. Then you got sick too and I knew you weren't going to make it..." he sobbed.  "Please, you're joking right? I mean, you're not being serious?" Jana asked with a wobble in her voice.  "Yes. Yes. All of this is the truth. The real truth. You were dying and all of your organs were shutting down. I couldn't lose you too. I just couldn't... I wouldn't be able to live with myself. But I knew the government was working on technology to build cyber bodies. And I knew it was still in its infancy. But I thought that maybe, just maybe, eventually I could use that technology to keep you alive.

Comme beaucoup de monde, je suis un mordu du voyage ; c'est peut-être votre cas aussi. Me concernant, mes choix de destination ont toujours un but, un fil rouge : l'écriture. Je les choisi donc souvent en fonction des lieux d'action de KATZEN, mon grand œuvre. Je vous présente ici quelques endroits que j'ai visité pour ce premier tome ... 1) Liège Bon, en réalité, ce n'est pas vraiment un voyage ... mais c'est ici que j'ai fait mes études ! Je connais donc un peu la ville par cœur ... La rencontre entre le félidé et Zoran se fait rue Louvrex à Liège, soit l'une des voies qui longent le Jardin Botanique. Je situe ce point de rencontre ici précisément (au cas où vous ne parvenez pas à faire un copier-coller, j'ai posté le lien dans les commentaires ...) : https://www.google.com/maps/@50.6350883,5.5637729,3a,90y,347.37h,92.27t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sxKuYlKC0WhjF9RTytQjbIA!2e0!7i13312!8i6656?hl=fr 2) Berlin Avant de partir visiter la capitale allemande, j'ignorais complétement que le palais du Reichstag se trouvait juste à côté de la Porte de Brandebourg ! J'ai donc dû retravailler entièrement le passage qui précède l'entrée des héros en Allemagne de l'Est ... J'en suis au final très heureux car cette petite contrainte a permis d'enrichir énormément les chapitres concernés. Ces photographies sont de moi ... Elles doivent vous rappeler de beaux souvenir (surtout la quatrième haha) :-)

1) Le style Le narrateur n'a pas une once d'omniscience ; il retranscrit uniquement ce que l'auteur accepte de lui montrer, c'est à dire une prise de vue ; à ce titre, la narrateur assiste à un spectacle au travers d'une caméra, son sens visuel étant le plus sollicité. Il est évidemment capable d'entendre ce qui se dit, comme dans tout roman ; ici, cela lui permet de mémoriser et de répéter les noms qui seront tôt ou tard prononcés au fil du récit ; il ne pourra donc pas les présenter avant qu'ils n'aient été portés à ses oreilles, il devra patienter pour en avoir connaissance. Le narrateur est incapable de retranscrire ce que les protagonistes ont en tête, il lui est impossible de lire dans les pensées, sauf quand l'auteur choisi de placer la caméra dans les souvenirs d'un personnage - il s'agira ici du déclenchement d'un flashback. Le narrateur, observant les émotions des protagonistes dans différentes situations, ne tire pas de conclusion hâtive sur leurs intentions et se prive des les juger ; sceptique, il utilisera régulièrement des adverbes de doute telles que "probablement", "peut-être", "certainement" lorsqu'il se permettra de donner ses impressions sur les potentielles préoccupations ou aspirations intérieures des personnages. Il est un ignorant qui s'assume, il préfère émettre des hypothèses ou se taire ; il travaille donc avec un esprit rationnel et scientifique, une approche primordiale dans la philosophie réaliste (nous y reviendrons dans la cinquième partie du making-of). L'auteur exige de ses personnages la politesse ! Ils ont une interdiction totale de prononcer des gros mots afin de ne pas troubler les chastes oreilles du narrateur. Il leur demande aussi, de même qu'à ce narrateur, de communiquer dans un langage courant ; quelques rares fois, quand l'occasion s'y prêtre vraiment, ils pourront se permettre un peu de langage familier mais jamais vulgaire. Cela fait partie des spécificités du récit afin, notamment, de permettre sa libre accessibilité aux lecteurs de 7 à 77 ans. 2) La conception d'un outil de travail La rédaction d'un roman étant très chronophage, j'ai désiré un outil pour me faciliter le travail d'écriture, et donc me permettre de gagner un temps précieux et considérable face au long et laborieux projet auquel je m'attelais. Comme vous le savez peut-être, je suis capable de confectionner des petites applications informatiques ... J'ai donc conçu puis amélioré au fil de l'avancée de KATZEN un programme permettant d'accéder directement, après avoir tapé un mot, à deux dictionnaires des noms communs en ligne, deux dictionnaires des synonymes, un dictionnaire de conjugaison, ... et plein d'autres petits bonus. Voici donc le  multi-dictionnaire de l'Université de l'Oesling , un outil de rêve pour tout écrivain ! Si vous voulez en savoir plus sur ses possibilités et son mode de fonctionnement, j'ai mis à la disposition de tous un petit livret que j'ai publié sur ma page wattpad ... Ce programme est disponible en ligne par ici : https://multi-dictionnaire.jmvanbeulen.com Bon amusement :-)

Illustration : Platon et Aristote devisant,  L'École d'Athènes , Raphaël (1509-1511) La philosophie idéaliste et son allégorie de la caverne inspirent de nombreux grands classiques de SF, en particulier les dystopies.  Le schéma est souvent le même : le héros découvre que le monde dans lequel il évolue cache une vérité effroyable, à tel point que, en parvenant à regarder au-delà des "apparences", il apprend que tout ce qui l'entoure est mauvais et accède petit à petit à une certaine connaissance ; surtout, il se rebelle afin de libérer sa société contre les forces du mal qui entravent son existence et donc le véritable "bonheur". Nous pourrions bien sûr développer le sujet en évoquant la gnose mais nous allons nous limiter à ça ... Étant au contraire sur une ligne aristotélicienne, j'ai basé mon travail sur la philosophie dite réaliste. Ici, le monde réel n'est pas du tout une mise en scène et certains protagonistes cherchent même à l'anéantir. C'est un autre point de départ. Par ailleurs, le terrible concept de Suggestion va, au niveau de son application politique, au-delà de la notion d'idéologie qui, par définition, forme un ensemble cohérent et sectaire d'idées ; la disparition de la réalité, dans ce récit, est plutôt vouée à permettre aux hommes d'accéder à un multivers illimité d'idées. En 2011 sort un film américain dénommé  Sucker Punch , l'histoire d'une jeune fille qui cherche à s'évader d'un hôpital psychiatrique en s'aidant de son imaginaire ... Le sous-titre de l'affiche m'avait interpellé :  Le réel est une prison, votre esprit est la clé . Je verrais bien ce slogan placardé partout dans les rues pour promouvoir la Suggestion et donc l'État Suggéré. D'un autre côté, par le biais de ce film, cette affiche a déjà bel et bien été placardée sur de nombreux espaces publicitaires du monde occidental ... Dans KATZEN, nous partons d'un postulat inverse en émettant une terrible interrogation : et si l'imagination, quelque part, devenait non plus une source d'évasion mais de détention ? Cette approche, évidemment, ne peut que perturber les grands lecteurs de romans ; vous qui lisez ces lignes êtes probablement concerné ... Pourtant, ne seriez-vous pas les premiers à dire que l'imagination sert à vous évader ? La suggestion, centrale en hypnose, est avant tout une idée, formulée verbalement ou non, qui est acceptée par le cerveau du sujet ; cela induit l'élaboration d'une pensée de son propre chef pouvant déboucher sur l'accomplissement d'un acte. L'hypnose suppose un état second, à l'instar du rêve, qui dissipe de facto la raison et la volonté, facilitant donc l'implémentation de l'idée à mesure de la plongée du sujet dans son état second. Sans nous en rendre compte, nous sommes hypnotisés en permanence, à des degrés divers bien sûr, notamment quand nous sommes immergés dans la lecture ou l'écoute d'une histoire captivante. Sans être praticien, j'utilise beaucoup une forme d'hypnose - à savoir, bien raconter une histoire - quand je dois m'occuper d'enfants par exemple ; cela les tranquillise. Ceci est un tuyau pour les instituteurs ... Malheureusement, l'hypnose est utilisée pour des buts moins louables, elle fait un excellent outil de propagande pour les sectes et idéologies ; je ne vous apprends évidemment rien ... Celles-ci nous proposent un imaginaire, le but étant de nous convaincre et donc de l'intégrer à notre conception du monde ; nous en savons quelque chose ces temps ci, nous le voyons tous les jours au travers de tous les néo-gourous ésotéristes du web qui profitent de la crise actuelle pour nous apporter l' illumination . KATZEN va plus loin ... Et si la suggestion en question était une auto-suggestion, non pas le rêve d'idéologues mais notre propre rêve qui auto-constituerais notre univers personnel au détriment de la réalité ? Nous nous éloignons ici, peut-être, du concept traditionnel de la "dictature" sur la société et la pensée, nous sommes plutôt dans le cas d'une auto-corruption de la liberté. Le libéralisme est une doctrine politique et philosophique qui, s'étant imposée à travers le monde au siècle dernier, n'est pas présentée - à juste titre - comme une idéologie. Sa grande idée est de placer la notion de liberté non pas comme un moyen d'atteindre le Bonheur mais comme une finalité dans nos vies, comme si la liberté était intrinsèque au Bonheur. Certaines personnes, suivant leurs convictions personnelles, seront en accord ou non avec ce concept. Toutefois, il est un fait que cette doctrine imbibe les récits dystopiques, la liberté y étant le but recherché ; du point de vue d'un libéral, il s'agit d'un excellent outil pour renforcer la cohésion sociale autour de ce grand projet ; du point de vue d'un anti-libéral qui analyse la chose, il s'agit d'un pur outil de propagande (bourgeoise pour les uns, mécréante pour les autres). Le libéralisme redéfinit et relativise, dans son essence même, la notion de Bien et de Mal, de Vrai et de Faux ; il ouvre la porte à toutes les dites-vérités, ou tout du moins les accepte à différents degrés de tolérance ; il transcende ainsi, de ce fait, la notion de réalité lui aussi. Dès lors, quelque part, la Suggestion n'est-elle pas l'accomplissement ultime de cette doctrine censée libérer les hommes ? Par conséquent ... Au fond, qui est le méchant, qui est le gentil dans KATZEN ? Tous les personnages principaux, quel que soit leur camp, n'ont-ils pas quasiment tous une face claire et une face sombre ? Le lecteur peut se poser librement des questions ... En tant que croyant, attaché à la pensée aristotélicienne de surcroît, j'avoue qu'il m'est personnellement facile de me poser toutes ces questions. Je sais que peu d'auteurs contemporains fonctionnent avec les mêmes paramètres ... mais si je peux favoriser le regard et le recul critique d'un ou plusieurs lecteurs sur notre monde, j'aurais déjà fait une partie de mon travail ... Je pourrais parler d'autres influences philosophiques sur KATZEN mais je vais en rester là pour l'instant ... Je referai un petit making-of du même genre à la fin du Tome 2. Un grand merci pour votre lecture ! JM Van Beulen

<< Elle est le sujet d'une expérience de Mégaclès. — ... Quoi ? — ... Votre sœur aînée est le sujet d'une expérience de votre fils. Il a un total contrôle sur elle. Il sait très bien ce qu'il lui arrive. Il l'a mise lui-même dans un état de transe hypnotique, c'est évident. >> Le Général Hélios Arkoudas, assis et penché en arrière derrière sa table de travail, les mains jointes derrière la tête, écoutait ce qu'était venu lui confier le Docteur Knut Moen dans son bureau. << C'est la conclusion que je viens de tirer avec Mademoiselle Clara Sørensen, la psychothérapeute qui s'occupe d'elle. Nous allons à présent tenter de comprendre quels sont les objectifs de Mégaclès. >> Le chef d'État-Major resta silencieux, l'esprit perceptiblement très préoccupé. Son instrument de mesure du temps émit soudainement un signal d'appel. << Une seconde ... >> Il décrocha. Une dame trentenaire apparut en plan poitrine dans une semi-holographie au-dessus de son poignet. Elle avait de longs cheveux qui, de teinture bleu ciel, étaient doublement tressés. << Oui ? — Général Arkoudas ... Mon nom est Hydroski. Je vous contacte au nom de la rébellion en Pologne ... >> Le timbre de sa voix, qui s'accompagnait d'un débit de mots relativement lent, était à peine moins laid que son visage. << Oui ... >> prononça le militaire. Elle reprit : << ... Nous savons où se cache Olivier Demester. L'information était donc vraie. Nos drones ont clairement localisé et identifié votre ancien camarade dans une forêt au centre des Sudètes. >> Zoran et le félidé de guerre entendirent des bruits de bottes puis des voix graves ordonnant à la foule de s'éloigner de la zone. Rapidement, l'ambiance s'attiédit. << Bon ... Ils vont bientôt entrer. Tu vas garder le silence. Tu vas leur dire que tu ne parleras qu'en présence de leur chef, comme convenu ... >> expliqua le félin noir en sautant hors du lit. Les miliciens se mirent à frapper la porte avec un bélier. Le chat grimpa sur la tablette de la fenêtre et pressa l'interrupteur auprès de la surface vitrée qui coulissa aussitôt. Un vent frais s'invita importunément dans la chambre. << Nous nous retrouverons à Riga. précisa le félin noir. — ... Non ... S'il te plaît ... J'aimerais que tout cela s'arrête. — À tout à l'heure ... >> Il sauta hors de la baie, disparaissant de la vue du jeune homme. La structure de bois sombra sous le troisième coup de bélier. Trois miliciens armés se disposèrent tactiquement dans la pièce. << Ne bouge pas ! Mains en l'air ! >> lui ordonna l'un d'eux. Le patient obtempéra immédiatement, comme d'ordinaire nettement apeuré dans de telles situations tendues. << Où est le chat ? >> Cette question, d'autres pouvaient se la poser aussi ; la Reine Hedwige, toujours assise sur la bergère dans un coin de la chambre où elle veillait encore sur le pauvre Boleslas endormi ; Klaus Friedrich, en treillis militaire, en train de courir intensivement sur un tapis roulant parmi plusieurs rangées de soldats qui, généralement plus jeunes que lui, faisaient de même dans une immense salle éclairée, les pupilles dilatées et le bras gauche orné d'un écusson représentant le soleil anthropomorphique de la Suggestion ; Casimir, étendu sur le matelas sordide de son cachot ; le Frère Oliwier, occupé dans la bibliothèque de l'Abbaye sudète à comparer la reconnaissance de caractères d'un vieux livre codex rédigé en latin avec un document numérique du même contenu affiché sur un transparent A4 ; Sélène, se mirant dans la glace de sa salle de bain ; Hélios, accoudé sur la rambarde de la terrasse attenante à la cantine du Campus, les yeux pointés sur les collines et les feuillus ardennais, un ballon de Sauternes à la main ; Léo Alekna, entrant à son tour dans la chambre et découvrant Zoran orienter ses pupilles vers la fenêtre encore ouverte d'où s'était échappé le félidé. FIN KATZEN - Tome 1 - Mémoire morte (JM Van Beulen) Dans l'opinion de tous les hommes, le bonheur est précisément le but où l'on se repose, loin de tout souci, dans le sein du plaisir. Aristote,  La politique

Un roman est en partie une autobiographie de son auteur ... C'est très vrai pour KATZEN. Comme je l'ai dit dans la fiche d'introduction au livre, j'ai commencé à songer à cette histoire vers l'âge de sept ou huit ans ; mon vécu personnel s'est chargé de la perfectionner ... Néanmoins, bien sûr, certaines œuvres artistiques ont eu un impact majeur dans mon inspiration. Je vais vous présenter celles qui, de mémoire, ont très certainement exercé leur influence sur l'ébauche de projet du roman KATZEN durant mon enfance et mon début d'adolescence. Un détail amusant : je réalise que ces œuvres sont éloignées dans le temps, elles appartiennent pour la plupart à une génération antérieure à ma naissance ; je peux remercier mes parents ... Vous savez ce que l'on des vieilles casseroles ... 1) Deux films américains (Disney) Connaissez-vous  Le chat qui vient de l'espace  ?  C'est un vieux film (1978) complétement oublié mais je fais partie des heureux à avoir pu le visionner à plusieurs reprises étant enfant ... Ce fut évidemment l'un de mes films préférés. Il raconte l'histoire d'un chat intelligent qui descend sur terre en soucoupe volante. Il peut parler et faire léviter des objets à l'aide de son collier. Si je me souviens bien, l'objet attirera la convoitise d'un groupe mafieux. Il y a aussi un film un peu plus classique mais que je trouvais néanmoins moins amusant - ce qui ne l'a pas empêché d'avoir le mérite de nourrir mon imagination - ,  L'espion aux pattes de velours  (1965). Il a eu droit à un remake en 1997. C'est l'histoire d'un (autre) chat siamois qui est témoin de l'enlèvement d'une dame. Un policier, pour retrouver le lieu de séquestration de celle-ci, va suivre le félin en l'équipant d'un appareil de géolocalisation. 2) Deux BD belges (Hergé) Combien de fois ai-je dévoré les bande-dessinées des baroudeurs  Tintin et Milou . Enquêtes  policières, aventures aux quatre coins du monde, espionnage, conspirations, inventions surprenantes ... La recette, facilement abordable pour les enfants, est assez mature pour plaire également aux adultes ; elle fascine tous les âges - des 7 aux 77 ans. Jo, Zette et Jocko , une autre série du même auteur qui est un peu moins connue, a aussi été une légère source d'inspiration. 3) Deux mangas japonais Je me suis rendu compte un peu tard que la scène d'ouverture de KATZEN peut légèrement rappeler celle d' Akira  de Katsuhiro Ōtomo (hélicoptère, militaires, fugitif à retrouver ...), un manga très célèbre qui a eu droit à une adaptation animée époustouflante. L'univers cyberpunk de  Ghost in the Shell   de Masamune Shirow pousse tellement à la réflexion sur le devenir de l'espèce humaine et sa société future qu'il m'a peut-être renforcé dans le désir d'enrichir KATZEN d'un puissant apport philosophique. Je vous en révèlerai plus à ce sujet dans la cinquième et dernière partie de ce making-of ...

Le félin noir grimpa sur le lit médicalisé. << Ils t'ont attaché ? — Oui. — Ça va, ce sont des menottes électroniques. >> Il planta ses griffes dans le bracelet caoutchouteux entourant le poignet de son compagnon d'aventure, provoquant sa décontraction juste après la très fugace apparition d'une étincelle bleuâtre. Le jeune homme put enfin dégager son bras. Certains poursuivants de la petite bête commencèrent à rudoyer le vantail qui leur bloquait le passage par de détonants coups de pied. << Allez ! On va l'avoir ! — Cette bestiole n'a plus d'issue ! — Ce n'est qu'un jeu, vous n'êtes pas obligés de défoncer la porte ... — Pour huit cent mille Eurobits, nous n'allons pas nous priver ! >> Le matou jeta un œil au coude du garçon en tenue de patient. << Tu as été blessé par les dragons ... — Oui ... J'avais aussi une jambe cassée ...  signala Zoran en se frottant l'articulation olécranienne. Je vais mieux. — Dans le temps, il aurait fallu attendre quelques mois pour te réparer ... — ... Et toi ? Tu es déjà guéri ? — Je t'expliquerai plus tard. En attendant, j'ai besoin de ton aide. — Non. Je ne veux pas continuer. — Écoute ... J'aimerais que tu te rendes au quartier général de la Milice des Lions et que tu y rencontres leur plus haut responsable. Si tu le mets en confiance, il pourra m'aider. — Non ! C'est terminé. Je vais rentrer en Pologne. — Ils ne te laisseront pas partir comme ça, ils savent certainement que tu proviens de l'État Suggéré ! Tu as besoin de mon aide comme j'ai besoin de la tienne. — Purée ... Mais ... je suis à bout. C'est trop pour moi ... Nous avons déjà failli mourir à plusieurs reprises ! — Zoran ... Fais ce que je te dis ! Tu n'as plus rien à perdre. >> De l'autre côté du mur, la température de l'agitation montait crescendo. D'autres patients, visiteurs et membres du personnel venaient s'ajouter à la foule, au moins par curiosité. Une dizaine de miliciens équipés de fusils Beyls et G36 firent irruption dans le corridor. Léo Alekna rejoignit ce groupe à la notable composition multiethnique et tout revêtu de noir. << Je veux ce chat en priorité ! Faites attention, le patient à l'intérieur provient de l'État Suggéré ! >> avisa-t-il aux hommes.
